revised_title: Investigation of the Slow Combustion of Methane, Methyl Alcohol, Formaldehyde, and Formic Acid
tldr: The authors conducted experiments to study the slow combustion of methane, methyl alcohol, formaldehyde, and formic acid. They found that the initial product of hydrocarbon combustion is the corresponding alcohol rather than the aldehyde. The experiments also showed that the duration of the induction period, a key characteristic of chain reactions, is influenced by surface conditions and can be affected by the presence of moisture, ultra-violet radiation, and certain third substances.
